greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Period of decimal representation of 1/n.
comment: Appears to be a divisor of A007733*A007736. - _Henry Bottomley_, Dec 20 2001
Primes p such that a(p)=p-1 are in A001913. [_Dmitry Kamenetsky_, Nov 13 2008]
When 1/n has a finite decimal expansion (namely, when n = 2^a*5^b), a(n) = 1 while A051626(n) = 0. - _M. F. Hasler_, Dec 14 2015
reference: J. H. Conway and R. K. Guy, The Book of Numbers, Copernicus Press, NY, 1996, pp. 159 etc.
link: Jon E. Schoenfield, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 terms from T. D. Noe)
Index entries for sequences related to decimal expansion of 1/n
formula: Note that if n=r*s where r is a power of 2 and s is odd then a(n)=a(s). Also if n=r*s where r is a power of 5 and s is not divisible by 5 then a(n) = a(s). So we just need a(n) for n not divisible by 2 or 5. This is the smallest number m such that n divides 10^m - 1; m is a divisor of phi(n), where phi = A000010.
phi(n) = n-1 only if n is prime and since a(n) divides phi(n), a(n) can only equal n-1 if n is prime. - Scott Hemphill (hemphill(AT)alumni.caltech.edu), Nov 23 2006
mathematica: Table[r = n/2^IntegerExponent[n, 2]/5^IntegerExponent[n, 5]; MultiplicativeOrder[10, r], {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Oct 17 2012 *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Hal Sampson [ hals(AT)easynet.com ]
